message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Past, Present, and Future of Aerial Robotic Manipulators
Paper Abstract: This article analyzes the evolution and current trends in aerial robotic manipulation, comprising helicopters, conventional underactuated multirotors, and multidirectional thrust platforms equipped with a wide variety of robotic manipulators capable of physically interacting with the environment. It also covers cooperative aerial manipulation and interconnected actuated multibody designs. The review is completed with developments in teleoperation, perception, and planning. Finally, a new generation of aerial robotic manipulators is presented with our vision of the future.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

I've completed the web search for "helicopter aircraft." Here's a summary of what I found:

## What is a Helicopter?

A helicopter is a type of rotorcraft in which lift and thrust are supplied by horizontally spinning rotors.(no content)This allows the helicopter to take off and land vertically, to hover, and to fly forward, backward and laterally.

## Key Features and Capabilities

Helicopters have several distinctive characteristics:
- These attributes allow helicopters to be used in congested or isolated areas.
- The benefit of using helicopters for these operations is that personnel and cargo can be moved to and from locations without requiring a runway for takeoffs and landings.

## Rotor Configurations

Helicopters use various rotor designs to counteract torque effects:
- Some helicopters use other anti-torque controls instead of the tail rotor, such as the ducted fan (called Fenestron or FANTAIL) and NOTAR, which provides anti-torque similar to the way a wing develops lift.
- The use of two or more horizontal rotors turning in opposite directions is another configuration used to counteract the effects of torque on the aircraft without relying on an anti-torque tail rotor, which allows the power normally required to be diverted for the tail rotor to be applied fully to the main rotors.

## Military Applications

Military helicopters play an integral part in the sea, land and air operations of modern military forces. They are used for transport, reconnaissance, anti-submarine warfare, and combat operations.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "multirotor drone"

Links: [{"title":"Multirotor - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multirotor"},{"title":"Drone warfare - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Drone_warfare"},{"title":"Unmanned aerial vehicle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unmanned_aerial_vehicle"},{"title":"Quadcopter - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quadcopter"},{"title":"MultiGP - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MultiGP"},{"title":"Hybrid drone - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybrid_drone"},{"title":"Dragon drone - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dragon_drone"},{"title":"Delivery drone - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Delivery_drone"},{"title":"List of unmanned aerial vehicles - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_unmanned_aerial_vehicles"},{"title":"R18 (drone)","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/R18_(drone)"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about multirotor drones:

## Definition

A multirotor or multicopter is a rotorcraft with more than two lift-generating rotors.

## How They Work

Unlike single- and double-rotor helicopters which use complex variable pitch rotors whose pitch varies as the blade rotates for flight stability and control, multirotors often use fixed-pitch blades; control of vehicle motion is achieved by varying the relative speed of each rotor to change the thrust and torque produced by each.

## Common Types

Due to their ease of both construction and control, multirotor aircraft are frequently used in radio control aircraft and unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) (drone) projects in which the names tricopter, quadcopter, hexacopter and octocopter are frequently used to refer to 3-, 4-, 6- and 8-rotor rotorcraft, respectively.

## Applications

Multirotor drones have diverse applications including:
- Aerial photography, area coverage, precision agriculture, forest fire monitoring, river monitoring, environmental monitoring, weather observation, policing and surveillance, infrastructure inspections, smuggling, product deliveries, entertainment and drone racing.
- Multirotor FPV drones have been used extensively by both armies for aerial reconnaissance and artillery spotting in the Russo-Ukraine War.

## Advantages

An advantage of multirotor aircraft is the simpler rotor mechanics required for flight control.

Web search results for query: "autonomous robot aerial vehicle"

Links: [{"title":"Unmanned aerial vehicle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unmanned_aerial_vehicle"},{"title":"Autonomous aircraft - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_aircraft"},{"title":"Autonomous robot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_robot"},{"title":"Unmanned combat aerial vehicle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unmanned_combat_aerial_vehicle"},{"title":"International Aerial Robotics Competition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Aerial_Robotics_Competition"},{"title":"Aerobot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aerobot"},{"title":"Micro air vehicle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Micro_air_vehicle"},{"title":"Mobile robot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mobile_robot"},{"title":"Drone in a Box - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Drone_in_a_Box"},{"title":"Uncrewed vehicle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uncrewed_vehicle"}]

I've completed a web search for "autonomous robot aerial vehicle." Here are the key findings:

## Key Definitions

An autonomous aircraft is an aircraft which flies under the control of on-board autonomous robotic systems and needs no intervention from a human pilot or remote control. More broadly, an unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) is defined as a "powered, aerial vehicle that does not carry a human operator, uses aerodynamic forces to provide vehicle lift, can fly autonomously or be piloted remotely, can be expendable or recoverable, and can carry a lethal or nonlethal payload".

## Applications and Development

Applications include aerial photography, area coverage, precision agriculture, forest fire monitoring, river monitoring, environmental monitoring, weather observation, policing and surveillance, infrastructure inspections, smuggling, product deliveries, entertainment and drone racing.(no content)Autonomous drones employ advanced technologies that allow them to carry out their missions without human intervention, such as cloud computing, computer vision, artificial intelligence, machine learning, deep learning, and thermal sensors.

## Competition and Innovation

Since 1991, collegiate teams with the backing of industry and government have fielded autonomous flying robots in an attempt to perform missions requiring robotic behaviors not previously exhibited by a flying machine.

## Recent Examples

The drone in a box is an emerging form of autonomous unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) technology that uses drones that deploy from and return to self-contained landing "boxes."

Links: [{"title":"Unmanned aerial vehicle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unmanned_aerial_vehicle"},{"title":"Autonomous aircraft - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_aircraft"},{"title":"Autonomous robot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_robot"},{"title":"Unmanned combat aerial vehicle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unmanned_combat_aerial_vehicle"},{"title":"International Aerial Robotics Competition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Aerial_Robotics_Competition"},{"title":"Aerobot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aerobot"},{"title":"Micro air vehicle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Micro_air_vehicle"},{"title":"Mobile robot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mobile_robot"},{"title":"Drone in a Box - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Drone_in_a_Box"},{"title":"Uncrewed vehicle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uncrewed_vehicle"}]

I've completed a web search for "autonomous robot aerial vehicle." Here are the key findings:

## Key Definitions

An autonomous aircraft is an aircraft which flies under the control of on-board autonomous robotic systems and needs no intervention from a human pilot or remote control. More broadly, an unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) is defined as a "powered, aerial vehicle that does not carry a human operator, uses aerodynamic forces to provide vehicle lift, can fly autonomously or be piloted remotely, can be expendable or recoverable, and can carry a lethal or nonlethal payload".

## Applications and Development

Applications include aerial photography, area coverage, precision agriculture, forest fire monitoring, river monitoring, environmental monitoring, weather observation, policing and surveillance, infrastructure inspections, smuggling, product deliveries, entertainment and drone racing.(no content)Autonomous drones employ advanced technologies that allow them to carry out their missions without human intervention, such as cloud computing, computer vision, artificial intelligence, machine learning, deep learning, and thermal sensors.

## Competition and Innovation

Since 1991, collegiate teams with the backing of industry and government have fielded autonomous flying robots in an attempt to perform missions requiring robotic behaviors not previously exhibited by a flying machine.

## Recent Examples

The drone in a box is an emerging form of autonomous unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) technology that uses drones that deploy from and return to self-contained landing "boxes."

message_text:
Web search results for query: "robotic manipulator"

Links: [{"title":"Manipulator (device) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Manipulator_(device)"},{"title":"Category:Robotic manipulators - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Robotic_manipulators"},{"title":"Serial manipulator - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Serial_manipulator"},{"title":"Robotic arm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robotic_arm"},{"title":"Mobile manipulator - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mobile_manipulator"},{"title":"Remote manipulator - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Remote_manipulator"},{"title":"Canadarm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Canadarm"},{"title":"Dextre - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dextre"},{"title":"Inverse kinematics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inverse_kinematics"},{"title":"Lyappa arm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyappa_arm"}]

Here's what I found about robotic manipulators:

## Definition and Purpose

In robotics, a manipulator is a device used to manipulate materials without direct physical contact by the operator.(no content)The applications were originally for dealing with radioactive or biohazardous materials, using robotic arms, or they were used in inaccessible places.

## Main Types

There are several key categories of robotic manipulators:

1. **Serial Manipulators**: Serial manipulators are the most common industrial robots and they are designed as a series of links connected by motor-actuated joints that extend from a base to an end-effector.(no content)Often they have an anthropomorphic arm structure described as having a "shoulder", an "elbow", and a "wrist".

2. **Parallel Manipulators**: Parallel manipulator – articulated robot or manipulator based on a number of kinematic chains, actuators and joints, in parallel.

3. **Remote Manipulators**: A remote manipulator, also known as a telefactor, telemanipulator, or waldo, is a device which, through electronic, hydraulic, or mechanical linkages, allows a hand-like mechanism to be controlled by a human operator.

4. **Mobile Manipulators**: A mobile manipulator is a robot system built from a robotic manipulator arm mounted on a mobile platform. A mobile robotic system combines the mobility offered by a mobile platform and dexterity offered by the manipulator.

## Applications

These robotic arms are used in manufacturing to do intricate and repetitive jobs with exceptional speed and accuracy, such as welding automotive parts and assembling electronic components.(no content)Mobile manipulators, either autonomous or remote operated, are used in many areas, such as space exploration, military operations, home care and health care.

Web search results for query: "perception computer vision"

Links: [{"title":"Machine perception - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Machine_perception"},{"title":"Computer vision - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computer_vision"},{"title":"Visual perception - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Visual_perception"},{"title":"Human visual system model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_visual_system_model"},{"title":"Active vision - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Active_vision"},{"title":"Thomas Binford - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thomas_Binford"},{"title":"Objective vision - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Objective_vision"},{"title":"Pattern recognition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pattern_recognition"},{"title":"Outline of computer vision - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Outline_of_computer_vision"},{"title":"Depth perception - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Depth_perception"}]

I've completed a web search for "perception computer vision" and found comprehensive information on the topic. Here's what the search revealed:

## Computer Vision

Computer vision is a field that includes methods for acquiring, processing, analyzing, and understanding images and high-dimensional data from the real world to produce numerical or symbolic information, e.g., in the forms of decisions. More specifically, computer vision is concerned with the automatic extraction, analysis, and understanding of useful information from a single image or a sequence of images, and involves the development of a theoretical and algorithmic basis to achieve automatic visual understanding.

## Applications and Subdisciplines

Computer vision has many applications already in use today such as facial recognition, geographical modeling, and even aesthetic judgment.(no content)Subdisciplines of computer vision include scene reconstruction, object detection, event detection, activity recognition, video tracking, object recognition, 3D pose estimation, learning, indexing, motion estimation, visual servoing, 3D scene modeling, and image restoration.

## Relationship to Human Vision

Some strands of computer vision research are closely related to the study of biological vision—indeed, just as many strands of AI research are closely tied with research into human intelligence and the use of stored knowledge to interpret, integrate, and utilize visual information.(no content)Computer vision develops and describes the algorithms implemented in software and hardware behind artificial vision systems.

## Challenges

Machines still struggle to interpret visual input accurately if it is blurry or if the viewpoint at which stimuli are viewed varies often. Computers also struggle to determine the proper nature of some stimulus if overlapped by or seamlessly touching another stimulus.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Web search results for query: "robot arm manipulator"

Links: [{"title":"Robotic arm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robotic_arm"},{"title":"Manipulator (device) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Manipulator_(device)"},{"title":"Serial manipulator - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Serial_manipulator"},{"title":"Mobile manipulator - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mobile_manipulator"},{"title":"Parallel manipulator - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parallel_manipulator"},{"title":"Stanford arm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stanford_arm"},{"title":"Industrial robot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Industrial_robot"},{"title":"Lyappa arm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyappa_arm"},{"title":"Snake-arm robot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Snake-arm_robot"},{"title":"Continuum robot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Continuum_robot"}]

I've completed the web search for "robot arm manipulator". Here are the key findings:

## Overview

A robotic arm is a type of mechanical arm, usually programmable, with similar functions to a human arm; the arm may be the sum total of the mechanism or may be part of a more complex robot.

## Key Characteristics

The links of such a manipulator are connected by joints allowing either rotational motion (such as in an articulated robot) or translational (linear) displacement.(no content)The terminus of the kinematic chain of the manipulator is called the end effector and it is analogous to the human hand.

## Types of Robot Manipulators

The search results identify several main types:

- **Serial Manipulators**: Serial manipulators are the most common industrial robots and they are designed as a series of links connected by motor-actuated joints that extend from a base to an end-effector.

- **Parallel Manipulators**: The end effector (or 'hand') of this linkage (or 'arm') is directly connected to its base by a number of (usually three or six) separate and independent linkages working simultaneously.

- **Mobile Manipulators**: A mobile manipulator is a robot system built from a robotic manipulator arm mounted on a mobile platform.

- **Snake-arm Robots**: A snake-arm robot is a slender hyper-redundant manipulator. The high number of degrees of freedom allows the arm to "snake" along a path or around an obstacle.

## Applications

These robotic arms are used in manufacturing to do intricate and repetitive jobs with exceptional speed and accuracy, such as welding automotive parts and assembling electronic components. They're also used in healthcare, logistics, agriculture, and space exploration.

- **Parallel Manipulators**: The end effector (or 'hand') of this linkage (or 'arm') is directly connected to its base by a number of (usually three or six) separate and independent linkages working simultaneously.

- **Mobile Manipulators**: A mobile manipulator is a robot system built from a robotic manipulator arm mounted on a mobile platform.

- **Snake-arm Robots**: A snake-arm robot is a slender hyper-redundant manipulator. The high number of degrees of freedom allows the arm to "snake" along a path or around an obstacle.

## Applications

These robotic arms are used in manufacturing to do intricate and repetitive jobs with exceptional speed and accuracy, such as welding automotive parts and assembling electronic components. They're also used in healthcare, logistics, agriculture, and space exploration.

Web search results for query: "motion planning algorithm"

Links: [{"title":"Motion planning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Motion_planning"},{"title":"Real-time path planning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Real-time_path_planning"},{"title":"Vector Field Histogram - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vector_Field_Histogram"},{"title":"Probabilistic roadmap - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Probabilistic_roadmap"},{"title":"Rapidly exploring random tree - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rapidly_exploring_random_tree"},{"title":"OMPL - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/OMPL"},{"title":"Velocity obstacle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Velocity_obstacle"},{"title":"OpenRAVE - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/OpenRAVE"},{"title":"Any-angle path planning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Block_A*"},{"title":"Visibility graph - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Visibility_graph"}]

## Motion Planning Algorithm

Here are the key findings from the search results:

### Definition and Purpose

Motion planning (also known as path planning, the navigation problem, or the piano mover's problem) is a computational problem to find a sequence of valid configurations that moves the object from the source to destination.(no content)The term is used in computational geometry, computer animation, robotics and computer games.

### Major Algorithm Categories

**Sampling-based Algorithms:**
Sampling-based algorithms are currently considered state-of-the-art for motion planning in high-dimensional spaces, and have been applied to problems which have dozens or even hundreds of dimensions.

**Grid-based Approaches:**
Grid-based approaches overlay a grid on configuration space and assume each configuration is identified with a grid point. At each grid point, the robot is allowed to move to adjacent grid points as long as the line between them is completely contained within free space. This discretizes the set of actions, and search algorithms (like A*) are used to find a path from the start to the goal.

### Notable Algorithm Examples

- **Probabilistic Roadmap (PRM):** The probabilistic roadmap planner is a motion planning algorithm in robotics, which solves the problem of determining a path between a starting configuration of the robot and a goal configuration while avoiding collisions.

- **Vector Field Histogram (VFH):** Vector Field Histogram (VFH) is a real time motion planning algorithm proposed by Johann Borenstein and Yoram Koren in 1991.

- **Velocity Obstacles:** A velocity obstacle is the set of all velocities of a robot that will result in a collision with another robot at some moment in time, assuming that the other robot maintains its current velocity.

### Applications

Motion planning is an important part of robotics as it allows robots to find the optimal path to a target. This ability to find an optimal path also plays an important role in other fields such as video games and gene sequencing.

Web search results for query: "teleoperation"

Links: [{"title":"Teleoperation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Teleoperation"},{"title":"Telerobotics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Telerobotics"},{"title":"Telepresence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Telepresence"},{"title":"Remote surgery - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Remote_surgery"},{"title":"Telehaptics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Telehaptics"},{"title":"Remote manipulator - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Remote_manipulator"},{"title":"Presence: Teleoperators & Virtual Environments - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Presence:_Teleoperators_&_Virtual_Environments"},{"title":"Raymond Goertz - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Raymond_Goertz"},{"title":"Talk:Telepresence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Telepresence"},{"title":"Optimus (robot) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Optimus_(robot)"}]

Here are the search results for **teleoperation**:

## Definition
Teleoperation (or remote operation) indicates operation of a system or machine at a distance.(no content)It is similar in meaning to the phrase "remote control" but is usually encountered in research, academia and technology.

## Common Applications
It is most commonly associated with robotics and mobile robots, but it has diverse uses across multiple industries:

- **Industrial and Hazardous Environments**: Industrial machinery is often operated remotely, particularly in hazardous environments. Examples include the construction of the Object Shelter or sarcophagus at Chernobyl after the Chernobyl accident, and removal of debris after hazardous rock slides. Remotely operated vehicles (ROVs) are extensively used in hazardous environments (i.e. radioactive environments, contaminated environments, minefields, deep oceans).

- **Hobby and Recreation**: Teleoperation is now moving into the hobby industry with first-person view (FPV) equipment. FPV equipment mounted on hobby cars, planes and helicopters give a TV-style transmission back to the operator, extending the range of the vehicle to greater than line-of-sight range.

- **Autonomous Vehicles**: Most leading companies in the industry believe that to bridge the gap between current self-driving capabilities and the requirements needed for widespread adoption of autonomous vehicles, there is a need to have teleoperation capabilities for assisting self-driving cars, in situations of 'edge cases' – where the autonomous vehicle software stack has low confidence level in its ability to perform the correct action.

- **Medical and Surgical**: Remote surgery (also known as cybersurgery or telesurgery) is the ability for a doctor to perform surgery on a patient even though they are not physically in the same location. It is a form of telepresence.

## Historical Context
The purpose of teleoperation has expanded beyond the scope of just safety and now includes uses such as reaching remote environments in space or deep underwater and working with manipulating extremely large or small objects for surgical operations or manufacturing, among many other uses.

For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm"), relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters
todos.activeForm: Editing triples_output.json with all triple information

todos.content: Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.
